author: Andrew Schroer
title: Bread Crumbs: Be God’s helping hand | Faith | victoriaadvocate.com
text: It’s hard to believe that it was seven years ago. I’ll never forget Hurricane Harvey. It wasn’t the only hurricane I’ve experienced here in south central Texas, but it was by and far the biggest and most damaging storm I have lived through. My most vivid memories of Hurricane Harvey, however, are not of the storm itself, but of the days and weeks which followed. Thirty volunteers from other parts of Texas descended on our church to spend four days in Edna, helping us and our neighbors clean up. Our national church body sent tools and supplies. Individuals from around the country donated thousands of dollars to disperse to those in need. Together with a crew from our church, the volunteers were able to assist over one hundred households in our community, clearing out trees and branches from yards, mending fallen fences, and temporarily patching roofs. The generosity of other Christians from here in Texas and around the country was truly a blessing to our small church and community. God and our neighbors stepped up in our time of need. I’m sure many living in the southeastern United States won’t soon forget Hurricane Helene. The huge hurricane hit Florida with a bang, but it didn’t stop there. It cut a path of destruction up through Georgia and the Carolinas and into Kentucky. People living hundreds of miles from the coast, who never dreamed they would experience the wrath of a hurricane, now find themselves where we were seven years ago. This last Sunday, we prayed for them at our church. We prayed that God give them hope and help and comfort in their time of need. What we sometimes forget as Christians is that we are often God’s answer to our prayers. What I mean is that God uses us to provide his help and hope and comfort to others. In many ways, we are God’s hands and feet and mouth here on earth. For those of us living on the Gulf Coast of Texas, we now have the opportunity to do just that—to be God’s hands and feet and mouth. We can give. We can go. We can help. We know firsthand how it feels to see our homes and yards and cars devastated by damage. We know how it feels to sit for days without electricity. We know that the cleanup and rebuilding doesn’t end when the camera crews move on and the next disaster dominates the news cycle. So, pray for the people who are still cleaning up and getting back on their feet after Hurricane Helene. But also remember that you may be the answer to that prayer. Give. Help. Volunteer. You know how encouraging it is to receive a helping hand.

author: Qhubo
title: Seis años de cárcel para actor que abusó de una actriz de ‘Patito Feo’ | El Universal.com
text: El reconocido actor Juan Darthés fue condenado a seis años de prisión por abusar sexualmente de su colega Thelma Fardin, con quien compartió créditos en la serie musical ‘Patito feo’ (2007-2011). Desde hace algunos años el brasileño ha estado involucrado en escándalos de abuso sexual. Varias actrices lo acusaron públicamente, pero Fardin fue quien lo denunció ante las autoridades. En 2017 la actriz Calu Rivero acusó a Darthés, sin denuncia penal, de haberla acosado durante el rodaje de la novela ‘Dulce amor’ (2012-2013). Ambos ya se conocían porque también trabajaron en ‘Patito feo’. A ella se sumaron las actrices Anita Coacci y Natalia Juncos. Lea aquí: Actor de Patito Feo fue condenado por abuso sexual a actriz de la serie Y en diciembre de 2018 quien hizo las acusaciones fue Thelma Fardin, quien a través de un video relató cómo fue abusada por su colega. Asimismo, interpuso una denuncia penal en la Fiscalía de Violencia de Género de Nicaragua, país donde sucedieron los hechos. En su video Fardin recordó que fue abusada sexualmente en 2009 cuando ella tenía 16 años y su colega 45. En ese entonces el elenco de ‘Patito feo’ estaba en Managua, hasta donde llegó la gira ‘Patito feo: el show más lindo’. Lea aquí: Video: ¡Es oficial! Christian Nodal confirmó su relación con Ángela Aguilar Lo que sucedió la actriz argentina, quien interpretó a Josefina Beltrán en aquella famosa serie, lo narró a través de un video publicado en Youtube. Tras varios años de proceso judicial, en mayo de 2023 Juan Darthés fue absuelto en un fallo de primera instancia. Sin embargo, un año después, este 10 de junio, en una segunda instancia el Tribunal Federal de Segunda Instancia de Brasil los condenó a seis años de cárcel por acceso carnal."}

author: Il Resto del Carlino
title: Battaglia sull'eolico: i comitati difendono. Parma e Petitti
text:
Sconcertano le dichiarazioni delle consigliere regionali Pd Alice Parma ed Emma Petitti contro gli impianti eolici in Toscana (ai confini con l’alta Valmarecchia). Lo sanno che è proprio per la carenza di fonti rinnovabili che in Italia abbiamo le bollette più alte? Annalisa Corrado, eurodeputata e responsabile nazionale Pd alla transizione ecologica, sconfessi le loro parole. È il duro attacco mosso dall’associazione Energia per l’Italia , dopo la presa di posizione di Petitti e Parma contro i progetti per gli impianti eolici.
In difesa delle consigliere, si schierano i comitati e le associazioni che si battono contro l’arrivo delle pale. "L’associazione Energia per l’Italia non può attaccare così le consigliere regionali Parma e Petitti e censurare la loro interrogazione, nata per tutelare il territorio dai maxi impianti eolici. Nel Montefeltro sono 8 i progetti presentati, con 58 pale alte fino a 200 metri. Se venissero installate, tra Romagna, Toscana e Marche, avremmo abbattimenti di ettari di bosco, rischi ambientali e di frane. Il disegno di legge della Toscana è scellerato".
Per questo le associazioni tornano a chiedere alla Regione Toscana di "di fermare i progetti. Non può non tenere conto delle pianificazioni dei territori confinanti, del parere negativo dell’Emilia Romagna e di altri enti".

author: Yahoo Finance
title: Garland County Sheriff’s Office confirm remains found belong to 19-year-old Amir Ellis
text:
KARK Garland County Sheriff’s Office confirm remains found belong to 19-year-old Amir Ellis Brandon Ringo December 28, 2023 at 11:17 PM · 1 min read Link Copied Read full article
GARLAND COUNTY, Ark. – Officials with the Garland County Sheriff’s Office confirmed that the human remains they discovered earlier this month belong to that of missing Hot Springs 19-year-old Amir Ellis.
The finding comes after deputies with the GCSO were dispatched to a location where human remains were found off of Hwy 7 North.
Hot Springs man still missing after multiple arrests made, mother asks for help
Deputies sent the remains to the Arkansas State Crime Lab and received the results back on Thursday confirming that the remains belong to Ellis.
Police said that Ellis has been missing since May and three suspects have been arrested in connection with his kidnapping.
Anyone with information regarding this investigation is asked to contact the GCSO at 501-622-3660.
For the latest news, weather, sports, and streaming video, head to KARK.
